item.title: Lithium discovery in US volcano could be biggest deposit ever found (www.chemistryworld.com)
item.description: Lithium discovery in US volcano could be biggest deposit ever found
item.content:encoded:
A new analysis suggests that a volcanic crater along the Nevada-Oregon border could contain the largest deposit of lithium ever found, surpassing the previously considered largest deposit in Bolivia. The estimated 20 to 40 million tonnes of lithium metal could have significant implications for the global lithium market, including price, supply security, and geopolitics. The deposit is composed of an unusual claystone called illite, which contains almost double the amount of lithium compared to the more common lithium-bearing clay mineral, magnesium smectite. Mining is expected to begin in 2026.

219 Points | 111 comments

item.title: Memories from Old LAN Parties (thomask.sdf.org)
item.description: Nostalgic Memories and Quirks of LAN Parties in the 2000s
item.content:encoded:
The author shares memories from LAN parties in the 2000s, highlighting the quirks and experiences that were unique to that era. From reinstalling Windows during an event to modding PC cases and dealing with stolen hard drives, the article captures the nostalgia and challenges of LAN gaming. It also mentions various tech-related anecdotes, such as using cracks, emulating CD drives, and the limitations of internet access at LANs.

79 Points | 36 comments

item.title: I used a Game Boy camera for Facetime video calls in iPadOS 17 (www.macstories.net)
item.description: 'I Used a Game Boy Camera for FaceTime Video Calls in iPadOS 17 and It Was Glorious'
item.content:encoded:
iPadOS 17 now supports UVC (USB Video Class) devices, allowing iPads to recognize external webcams, cameras, and other devices connected over USB-C. Federico Viticci tested this feature and found that he could use a Game Boy Camera as his iPad Pro's webcam during FaceTime calls. He also experimented with using a game capture card to play Nintendo Switch and Steam Deck games on his iPad's display. This unexpected functionality showcases the versatility of iPadOS 17 and its potential for creative and gaming applications.

172 Points | 17 comments

item.title: Asking 60 LLMs a set of 20 questions (benchmarks.llmonitor.com)
item.description: 'Script Tests Reasoning and Creativity of 60+ Models Using Prompts'
item.content:encoded:
A script was created to ask prompts testing reasoning, instruction following, and creativity to around 60 models. The answers were stored in a SQLite database. The prompts covered various topics such as arguing for and against the use of Kubernetes, explaining quantum field theory to a high-school student, and finding the next 20 leap years. The script used a mix of APIs from different platforms. The creator plans to improve the script by using better stop sequences and prompt formatting tailored to each model.

508 Points | 276 comments

item.title: Coffee in a Can (one-from-nippon.ghost.io)
item.description: The Rise of Japan's Canned Coffee Industry
item.content:encoded:
Japan's canned coffee industry, which started in 1969, has become a multi-billion dollar business. The first canned coffee was created by Tadao Ueshima, the CEO of UCC Coffee, who wanted a portable coffee option. Despite initial skepticism, canned coffee gained popularity, especially during the 1970 Osaka World Fair. Coca Cola and Suntory also entered the market, with Coca Cola's Georgia coffee becoming their best-selling product in Japan. The success of canned coffee is attributed to the convenience of cans and vending machines.

26 Points | 6 comments

item.title: Unpacking Elixir: Real-Time and Latency (underjord.io)
item.description: Unpacking Elixir: Prioritizing Low Latency and User Experience
item.content:encoded:
Elixir, built on Erlang, prioritizes consistently low latency and a near-realtime experience. It is suitable for systems where latency matters and a good user experience is necessary. Erlang's design allows for fair distribution of computational resources and prevents heavy work from blocking progress. Elixir has been used in messaging applications like Whatsapp and Discord, as well as in web frameworks like Phoenix LiveView.

13 Points | 0 comments

item.title: SmartKnob – Haptic input knob with software-defined endstops and virtual detents (github.com)
item.description: SmartKnob: An Open-Source Input Device with Software-Configurable Endstops and Virtual Detents
item.content:encoded:
SmartKnob is an open-source input device with software-configurable endstops and virtual detents. It uses a brushless gimbal motor paired with a magnetic encoder for closed-loop torque feedback control. The device is not yet recommended for general use due to potential mechanical and electrical revisions. The project is under active development and encourages community participation.

71 Points | 13 comments

item.title: Researchers use AI to find new magnetic materials without critical elements (phys.org)
item.description: Researchers Use AI to Predict Curie Temperature of New Magnetic Materials
item.content:encoded:
Scientists from Ames National Laboratory have developed a machine learning model that can predict the Curie temperature of new material combinations, a crucial factor in designing permanent magnet materials. This model is a significant step towards using artificial intelligence to discover new magnetic materials without critical elements like cobalt and rare earth elements. The team trained the model using experimental data and theoretical modeling, saving time and resources compared to traditional experimentation. The success of the model in predicting the Curie temperature of material candidates shows promise for designing new permanent magnets for various technological applications.

14 Points | 0 comments

item.title: GitHub – GSA/code-gov: An informative repo for all Code.gov repos (github.com)
item.description: Code.gov: Promoting Good Practices in Code Development and Collaboration
item.content:encoded:
Code.gov is a program and technical platform that promotes good practices in code development, collaboration, and reuse across the U.S. Federal Government. It provides tools and guidance to help federal agencies implement the Federal Source Code Policy and aggregates an inventory of the government's custom code. The repository contains various files related to code inventory, metadata, and administrative procedures. It is open source and encourages contributions from the public.

4 Points | 0 comments

item.title: Show HN: I built a Python web framework (github.com)
item.description: 'view.py: A Lightning-Fast and Modern Web Framework in Alpha Stage'
item.content:encoded:
view.py is a lightning-fast, modern web framework that is currently in a high alpha stage of development. It requires CPython 3.8+ for installation. The framework offers a simple and efficient way to build web applications. It is actively seeking new contributors and provides installation instructions for Linux/macOS and Windows. view.py aims to provide a fast and modern solution for web development.

114 Points | 57 comments

item.title: Every type of plastic used by LEGO (2022) (bricknerd.com)
item.description: The Many Types of Plastic Used By LEGO
item.content:encoded:
LEGO uses a variety of plastics for their bricks, including CA, HIPS, Bakelite, ABS, SAN, PP, PC, MABS, PA, POM, TP, PE, MTPO, TPU, SEBS, and PET. Each plastic has its own properties and uses, with ABS being the most commonly used since 1963. LEGO is also investing in developing sustainable materials and has already started using plant-sourced polyethylene and phasing out plastic shopping bags.

288 Points | 97 comments

item.title: Microsoft announces purchase of 315k tonnes of CO2 removal (www.heirloomcarbon.com)
item.description: Microsoft Signs Major CO2 Removal Deal with Heirloom
item.content:encoded:
Microsoft has signed a long-term contract to purchase up to 315,000 metric tons of CO2 removal over a multi-year period from Heirloom, a Direct Air Capture company. This is one of the largest carbon dioxide removal deals to-date. The agreement provides crucial funding for Heirloom to finance future Direct Air Capture facilities and supports Microsoft's goal to become carbon negative by 2030. The deal also advances the U.S.' climate leadership globally and contributes to the First Movers Coalition's efforts to combat climate change.

40 Points | 26 comments

item.title: Jakob Nielsen: The Top Web Design Mistakes of 1999 (1999) (www.nngroup.com)
item.description: The Top 10 Web Design Mistakes of 1999
item.content:encoded:
New technology and conventions have led to several new classes of usability problems in Web design. The article highlights the top 10 design mistakes of 1999, including breaking or slowing down the back button, opening new browser windows, non-standard use of GUI widgets, lack of biographies, lack of archives, moving pages to new URLs, headlines that make no sense out of context, jumping at the latest internet buzzword, slow server response times, and anything that looks like advertising.

4 Points | 0 comments

item.title: The Le Guin Precepts (seths.blog)
item.description: Ursula Le Guin's Three Questions for Evaluating Ideas and Actions
item.content:encoded:
Fabled author Ursula Le Guin's sign over her desk asked three questions: Is it true? Is it necessary or at least useful? Is it compassionate or at least unharmful? This serves as a good starting point for evaluating ideas and actions.

27 Points | 2 comments

item.title: FFmpeg Patches for a 20% speedup of Apple ProRes decoding (ffmpeg.org)
item.description: 'FFmpeg' Patch Improves Proresdec2 Performance with Cached Reader
item.content:encoded:
This patch for FFmpeg's proresdec2 fixes and ports the cached reader. The changes include moving back to the regular get_bits API, reducing the lookup to switch the coding method, and using shorter reads for the end of the bitstream. The patch also provides speedup results for Win64 and Win32 platforms. The cached reader version shows a 20% speedup on Win64 and a 14% speedup on Win32.

120 Points | 23 comments

item.title: Freshpaint (YC S19) is hiring engineers to build a HIPAA compliant data platform (jobs.ashbyhq.com)
item.description: Freshpaint: Simplifying Customer Data Collection and Integration
item.content:encoded:
Freshpaint is a Customer Data Platform that helps businesses collect and integrate customer data. They offer a PHI Management Platform for healthcare providers and a Customer Data Platform for teams to collect and activate customer data. The company is fully remote and values freedom and ownership in work. They are backed by leading investors and have a deep analytics and growth experienced team. The role of Software Engineer at Freshpaint involves scaling infrastructure, designing new data processing systems, and building user experiences.

1 Points | 0 comments

item.title: PAROL6 Desktop Robot Arm (github.com)
item.description: 'PAROL6: A High-Performance 3D-Printed Desktop Robotic Arm with Open-Source Design'
item.content:encoded:
PAROL6 is a high-performance 3D-printed desktop robotic arm that aims to mimic industrial robots in terms of design and usability. The control software, GUI, and STL files are open-source, allowing users to build their own PAROL6 robot by following the provided instructions. The project welcomes donations, advice, and contributions to support its open-source nature. The code and STL files are under the GPLv3 License.

item.title: A test of memory for stimulus sequences in great apes (neurosciencenews.com)
item.description: Sequential Memory Is a Unique Human Trait
item.content:encoded:
Humans possess a unique ability to recognize and remember sequential information, according to a study. Bonobos, our closest relatives, struggle to learn the order of stimuli in the same way as humans. This finding sheds light on the cognitive distinctions between humans and other animals, explaining why only humans possess certain cultural abilities like language and advanced planning. Sequential memory may be the foundational block behind many uniquely human behaviors and capabilities.

item.title: The era-defining aesthetic of “In the Mood for Love” (www.newyorker.com)
item.description: 'In the Mood for Love': Wong Kar Wai's Influential Masterpiece
item.content:encoded:
Wong Kar Wai's 2000 film 'In the Mood for Love' has had a significant influence on popular culture, with its unique aesthetic and storytelling. The film, set in 1960s Hong Kong, follows two individuals who discover that their spouses are having an affair and become entangled themselves. Wong's personal history and diverse influences shaped the film's style, which combines elements of French New Wave filmmaking, American mystery, and Chinese literature. 'In the Mood for Love' is a visually stunning and emotionally resonant work that continues to captivate audiences.

42 Points | 12 comments

item.title: A Teen Celebrity in 1804 (daily.jstor.org)
item.description: 'A Teen Celebrity in 1804: The Phenomenon of Bettymania and the Fleeting Nature of Child Stardom'
item.content:encoded:
In 1804, thirteen-year-old actor William Henry West Betty became a sensation in London, with crowds mobbing theaters and camped outside his home. This article explores the phenomenon of Bettymania and how it was carefully orchestrated through paid critics, merchandise, and strategic audience placement. While some critics saw it as a national embarrassment, Betty's fame and fee skyrocketed, but he eventually faded from the public eye. This story sheds light on the early history of celebrity culture and the fleeting nature of child stardom.

9 Points | 1 comments

item.title: Dennis Austin, developer of PowerPoint, has died (www.washingtonpost.com)
item.description: 'Dennis Austin, Principal Software Developer of PowerPoint, Dies at 76'
item.content:encoded:
Dennis Austin, the principal software developer of PowerPoint, has passed away at the age of 76. Austin played a significant role in shaping how information is communicated in modern society through the development of PowerPoint. The software, which was released in 1987, revolutionized the creation of slides and became a ubiquitous tool in offices, classrooms, and government agencies. Despite its widespread use, PowerPoint has also faced criticism for its potential to create mind-numbing presentations filled with bullet points. Austin's contributions to the software were instrumental in its success.

100 Points | 137 comments

item.title: The Rise and Fall of ESPN’s Leverage (stratechery.com)
item.description: The Rise and Fall of ESPN's Leverage
item.content:encoded:
The rise and fall of ESPN's leverage is explored, starting with the origins of the idea for ESPN and how it leveraged satellite communications to reach every home in America. The article then delves into the evolution of ESPN's business model, including the introduction of affiliate fees and the importance of diverse programming. The current standoff between Charter and Disney, which has resulted in channels going dark for Charter subscribers, is also highlighted.

9 Points | 4 comments

item.title: The English cottage where John le Carré wrote Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy (lithub.com)
item.description: 'John Le Carré's Cornwall Home, Tregiffian Cottage, Hits the Market for $3.7 Million'
item.content:encoded:
John Le Carré's Cornwall home, Tregiffian Cottage, is up for sale for $3.7 million. The 5,000-square-foot house, where Le Carré wrote many of his novels, features a detached writing studio, a library with bespoke joinery, and a safe room. The property offers stunning views and a picturesque setting. Le Carré's son, Nick Cornwell, described the cottage as a place filled with wildlife and natural beauty, making it an ideal space for rest, work, or self-reflection.

41 Points | 45 comments

item.title: Starfield’s missing Nvidia DLSS support has been added by a free mod (arstechnica.com)
item.description: Starfield modders add Nvidia DLSS support, but full support hidden behind Patreon paywall
item.content:encoded:
Modders have added Nvidia DLSS support to the game Starfield through a free mod, but full DLSS3 support is only available through a Patreon subscription. The mod, called Starfield Upscaler, is currently the most popular Starfield mod on NexusMods. However, the practical effect of DLSS support may be hard to notice for many players. AMD has not ruled out the possibility of adding DLSS support to Starfield in the future.

7 Points | 2 comments

item.title: On Desktop GUI Minimalism (mycophobia.org)
item.description: Reflections on Linux Desktop Environments and the Quest for a Minimalist GUI
item.content:encoded:
The author reflects on their experience with different desktop environments in Linux and their desire for a minimalist GUI. They discuss the evolution of GUIs, the influence of the original Macintosh interface, and their vision for a GUI environment that combines the flexibility of a window manager with the usability of a desktop. The author explores concepts such as spatial file management, customizable application launchers, and the need for efficient task management. They conclude by advocating for a GUI that prioritizes maximum usability and flexibility with minimal components.

44 Points | 28 comments

item.title: Making a newsletter backend (axleos.com)
item.description: Implementing a Bespoke Newsletter Service with a Personal Touch
item.content:encoded:
The author discusses their project of implementing a bespoke newsletter service. They outline the tech stack they plan to use and address potential abuse scenarios and failure cases. The author also mentions their experience with accessing SendGrid and adds a personal touch to the emails sent through the service.

item.title: Florida’s “Nub City,” Where Residents Cut Off Their Own Appendages for Insurance (allthatsinteresting.com)
item.description: 'Nub City': The Florida Town Where Residents Cut Off Their Own Limbs for Insurance Money
item.content:encoded:
Residents of Vernon, Florida engaged in a widespread insurance scam in the late 1950s and early 60s, intentionally dismembering themselves for a payout. The town became known as 'Nub City' due to the high number of loss-of-limb accident claims. The scam ended in the late 1960s when premium rates became too high and insurers stopped doing business in the area.

item.description: 'The Potential of Linux and Dealing with Difficult Developers: Daniel Robbins' Linux Journey'
item.content:encoded:
Daniel Robbins shares his Linux journey, from becoming a Stampede Linux developer to starting his own distribution called Enoch. He emphasizes the potential of Linux to change, improve, and break things, as well as the importance of the Linux community. Robbins also discusses his experience dealing with difficult developers and offers advice on managing them.
